ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I have learned to think critically in the lab, convey my research project to people unfamiliar with Lupus Nephritis, present biology information in front of others, and engage in wet lab research and imaging.
I learned how to perform independent research and write grant proposals.
Critical research skills
Research
I'm learning how to properly navigate my way through scientific research, while conducting outside research to ensure I remain updated when it comes to my field of study.
Varies depending on everyone's project, but mine was a microbiology project. I learnt a lot about bacterial growth and genetics.
I learned techniques of biological and biochemical research, metabolic theory, and what working in a lab looks like.
This is literally just your thesis research... not much to evaluate.
Research in my lab. Lots of skills I learned in previous research summers helped with this course. Writing proposals, presenting, etc
I gained significant hands-on research experience and knowledge of what it is like to be a part of a high level lab.

The research itself was absolutely fascinating and I learned a great deal. I learned several lab techniques: how to perform thorough dissections, how to plate and differentiate cell culture, how to run FLOW, how to construct graphs in prism, how to stain for lipids, and so much more.  I also learned how to construct my own experimental timeline and navigate general problems that arise when conducting research.
I gained experience conducting research, analyzing data, and writing a grant proposal.
Laboratory techniques in immunology and molecular biology.
Whegdgehwhwhagagwgdg

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: I love being in the lab and my PI is fantastic. 

Weaknesses: I wish we had more interactions with the MCDB 485 course professors who read our proposals and grants. A meeting at the beginning of the year would have been great.
Strengths: lots of independence on project, but also many opportunities to interact with my PI and receive feedback/guidance/mentorship along the way
I think this course depends on your relationship with your PI.
depends on how much you like research and your connection to your thesis lab
Very good. Loved how it was independent and I could choose my own project.

This "course" provides students with very little information, which is at times frustrated. For example, there is very little instruction about the requirements for the proposals due at the beginning and end of the semester. This is extremely frustrating for students.

It would be helpful to be able to engage with other students doing senior research and hear about their progress and struggles. This could be in the form of a "Research Update Meeting" so course instructors can check in with students in different labs.
It is great for the research experience but very inconsistent from lab to lab.

The research was great, but there wasn't too much to the course itself. I wish there had been a little more personal advisement at the start of the course. Even an email saying "we will check in at the end of the semester but if you have questions in the meantime, don't hesitate to reach out." Instead all of the information was in the syllabus, so it was up to the students to read it and direct themselves. I was kinda confused about the general structure of the "course" and honestly didn't really know who was in charge.
I spent more than the required amount of time in lab each week, so I appreciate that there were not very many additional requirements or assignments. Writing the grant proposal was useful.
Going into the lab 10+ hours a week is great because you can get a lot of research done throughout the semester!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Any MCDB student who is interested in wet lab research should take this course!
It's required to graduate
odds are that you're taking this class for the requirement so yes to finish the degree!
Yes it's a cool way to do your own project. Also no exams or quizzes or anything so it's a nice different pace from the rest of the classes
Yes if you want a really good exposure to a lab environment.
Again... this is your thesis.
If you need it to get a BS in MCDB
It is required for the BS in MCDB, but if you are interested in research, then take it.
It is a requirement. I would say the MCDB thesis class is more relaxed than some of the other majors.
Yes! I have gained valuable research experience and learned so much.

Yes, great way to get hands-on laboratory research experience in a real biology lab, and receive mentorship from real scientists that are passionate about their field of study. Also great opportunity to practice scientific grant writing at the end of the semester.
